title: Behind the scenes at the Framing Department | The National Gallery, London
description:
Most visitors to the National Gallery come to look at the paintings. But in this behind-the-scenes look at the work of the Gallery’s Framing Department, the richness and importance of the collection’s frames is revealed.

A fascinating insight into recent conservation work and historic frame purchases with the National Gallery’s Head of Framing, Peter Schade, and Vivmar Curatorial Assistant, Harriet O’Neill.

title: Intro to linear equation standard form
description: The standard form for linear equations in two variables is Ax+By=C. For example, 2x+3y=5 is a linear equation in standard form. When an equation is given in this form, it's pretty easy to find both intercepts (x and y). This form is also very useful when solving systems of two linear equations.

title: Van Dyck's Self-portrait: The Frame and its Conservation
description:
Jacob Simon and Stuart Ager consider the portrait's extraordinary frame, explaining its significance and challenges for conservation.

Find out more about Van Dyck's final self-portrait and its national tour here: http://ow.ly/HfLOy

title: Inputs and outputs of a function

title: Kasbah Taourirt: Conserving Earthen Heritage in Morocco
description:
Learn how the GCI and CERKAS partnered to develop a Conservation and Rehabilitation Plan for  Kasbah Taourirt in Ouarzazate, Morocco. 
________________________
The oasis valleys of southern Morocco are home to thousands of earthen kasbahs and ksours, or fortified earthen settlements. 

From 2011 to 2016, the Getty Conservation Institute partnered with the Centre de Conservation et de Réhabilation du Patrimoine Architectural Atlasiques et Subatlasiques (CERKAS) in Morocco to develop a Conservation and Rehabilitation Plan for one of the region's most significant settlements, Kasbah Taourirt in Ouarzazate. 

Learn more about this project: http://bit.ly/1j5W122

title: What is the domain of a function?
description: Functions assign outputs to inputs. The domain of a function is the set of all possible inputs for the function. For example, the domain of f(x)=x² is all real numbers, and the domain of g(x)=1/x is all real numbers except for x=0. We can also define special functions whose domains are more limited.

Sequences intro
description: Sequences are ordered lists of numbers (called "terms"), like 2,5,8. Some sequences follow a specific pattern that can be used to extend them indefinitely. For example, 2,5,8 follows the pattern "add 3," and now we can continue the sequence. Sequences can have formulas that tell us how to find any term in the sequence. For example, 2,5,8,... can be represented by the formula 2+3(n-1).

title: Systems of equations with elimination: apples and oranges
description: Sal solves a word problem about the price of apples and oranges by creating a system of equations and solving it.

description: Given that f(x)=2x√5-4 and g(x)=x^2+2x√5-1, Sal finds (g-f)(x).

title: Intro to polynomial synthetic division
description: Sal shows how synthetic division of polynomials works.

title: Scaling & reflecting absolute value functions: equation
description: The graph of y=k|x| is the graph of y=|x| scaled by a factor of |k|. If k<0, it's also reflected (or "flipped") across the x-axis. In this worked example, we find the equation of an absolute value function from a description of the transformation performed on y=|x|.

title: Writing systems of inequalities word problem
description: Sal models a word problem about baking cupcakes and muffins by creating a system of linear inequalities.

title: Scaling & reflecting absolute value functions: graph
description: The graph of y=k|x| is the graph of y=|x| scaled by a factor of |k|. If k<0, it's also reflected (or "flipped") across the x-axis. In this worked example, we find the equation of an absolute value function from its graph.

title: Systems of equations with elimination: coffee and croissants
description: Sal solves a word problem about the price of coffee and croissant by creating a system of equations and solving it.

title: Keynesian economics and its critiques
description: Learn about the Keynesian way of thinking about macroeconomic issues, and critiques of the Keynesian approach in this lesson.

title: Keynesian economics
description: Contrasting Keynesian and Classical Thinking

title: Solving systems of inequalities word problem
description: Given a system of linear inequalities that models a context about making chairs and tables, Sal finds how many can be made.

title: Keynes’ Law and Say’s Law in the AD/AS model
description: Compare Keynes and Say in the context of aggregate supply and demand

title: The parts of polynomial expressions

title: 4th & 5th roots
description: Radicals are also known as roots. The most common are square root √ and cube root ∛, but there are more. Evaluate higher-degree radicals like ∜81.

title: Unit-fraction exponents
description: Evaluate numerical expressions with unit-fraction exponents or radicals, and convert between the two forms of representations.

title: Exponential equation with rational answer
description: A worked example of rewriting a radical as an exponent. In this example, we solve for the unknown in 3ᵃ = ⁵√(3²).

title: Simplifying quotient of powers (rational exponents)
description: Sal simplifies the expression m^(7/9) / m^(1/3) as a single exponential term m^(4/9).

title: Graphing exponential growth & decay
description: Graphing the exponential functions y=27⋅(⅓)ˣ and y=-30⋅2ˣ.

description: Sal analyzes a polynomial subtraction process to find the step that has an error.

title: Scale & reflect absolute value graphs
description: y=a|x| is a stretched/shrunk version of the absolute value function y=|x|. Practice this relationship between the graphical and algebraic representations of absolute value functions.

title: Risks of Keynesian thinking
description: Why Keynesian thinking might not be ideal sometimes

title: Graphs of systems of inequalities word problem

title: Graphing absolute value functions
description: We can graph any equation of the form y=k|x-a|+h by thinking about function transformations (shifts, reflections, and scalings).

title: Macroeconomic perspectives on demand and supply
description: Read about the differing macroeconomic perspectives of Keynes and Say

title: Graph absolute value functions
description: Graph absolute value functions like f(x)=|x+3|+2.

title: National income and inequality
description: In this tutorial we will dig a bit into Thomas Piketty's popular "Capital in the 21st Century" that attempts to analyze the relationship(s) between economic growth, returns on capital and inequality. Our intent is to neither argue for nor against the ideas in the book, but rather use it as a tool for critical reasoning and discourse.

title: Systems of inequalities word problems
description: Solve word problems that involve systems of linear inequalities.

title: Absolute value graphs review
description: The general form of an absolute value function is f(x)=a|x-h|+k. From this form, we can draw graphs. This article reviews how to draw the graphs of absolute value functions.

title: Analyzing structure with linear inequalities: fruits
description: Given a real-world context about the number of fruits bought, we find a linear inequality that correctly depicts the situation.

title: Piecewise functions
description: We are used to functions that have the same rule for all inputs. For example, f(x)=x² outputs the square of every input. Piecewise functions have different output rules, depending on the inputs. For example, we can define function g to output x² for all positive values of x and x³ for all negative values of x, so g(2)=4 and g(-2)=-8.

title: Analyzing structure with linear inequalities: balls
description: Given a real-world context about the number of balls in a bag, we find a linear inequality that correctly depicts the situation.

title: Introduction to piecewise functions
description: Functions assign outputs to inputs. Some functions have simple rules, like "for every x, return x²." However, there can be other rules that are more elaborate. For example, "If x<0, return 2x, and if x≥0, return 3x." These are called *piecewise functions*, because their rules aren't uniform, but consist of multiple pieces

title: Analyzing structure with linear inequalities
description: Given some information about a real-world context, analyze expressions containing unknown variables that model that context.

title: The Phillips curve in the Keynesian perspective
description: Read about how we can use the Keynesian perspective to think about the common tradeoff between low inflation and low unemployment.

title: Worked example: evaluating piecewise functions
description: Evaluating piecewise functions at given inputs, both from a formula and from a graph.

title: The Keynesian perspective on market forces
description: They Keynesian economic perspective argues for government intervention in certain cases, but market forces are still valuable.

title: Evaluate piecewise functions
description: Given the formula of a piecewise function, evaluate it for a specific input.

title: Evaluate step functions
description: Given the graph of a step function, find the function's outputs for given specific inputs.

title: Worked example: graphing piecewise functions
description: Graphing a piecewise function given its formula. In this case, the function consists of three separate lines.

title: Education as a force of convergence
Exponent properties review
description: Practice using the exponent properties to rewrite powers, where the exponent is an integer that can either be positive or negative.

title: Exponential vs. linear growth
description: Learn about exponential growth and decay, and specifically how it always grows (or diminishes) by equal factors.

title: Piecewise functions graphs
description: Match the formula of a piecewise function to its graph.

title: Intro to exponential functions
description: In exponential functions the variable is in the exponent, like y=3ˣ. Here we introduce this concept with a few examples.

title: Adding & subtracting multiple polynomials
description: Sal simplifies (x³ + 3x - 6) + (-2x² + x - 2) - (3x - 4).

title: Graphs of exponential growth
description: Start exploring the relationship between exponential functions and their graphs.

title: Worked example: domain & range of step function
description: Finding the domain and range of a piecewise function that is constant in each segment. Such functions are called "step functions."

title: Inverse relationship between capital price and returns
Exponential vs. linear growth
description: For constant increments in x, a linear growth would increase by a constant difference, and an exponential growth would increase by a constant ratio.

title: Worked example: domain & range of piecewise linear functions
description: Finding the domain and range of a piecewise function where each segment is linear.

title: Connecting income to capital growth and potential inequality
Warmup: exponential vs. linear growth
description: Make sure you have a good understanding of the difference between exponential and linear growth, before taking our exercise.

title: r greater than g but less inequality
Exponential vs. linear growth
description: Identify whether a function (given as a table) grows linearly or exponentially.

title: Return on capital and economic growth
Radicals
description: Radicals (also known as roots) are a generalization of square roots. They are the inverse operation of any power. For example, the 5th root of 32 is 2, because 2⁵=32.

title: Exponential vs. linear  models: verbal
description: Sal sorts various descriptions of real-world situation according to the type of growth they describe: linear or exponential.

title: Critically looking at data on ROC and economic growth over millenia
Intro to polynomials
description: Learn about polynomial expressions: What are they? How are they constructed? What can we do with them?

title: Exponential vs. linear models: table
description: Determining whether real world model is linear or exponential, where the model is given as a table.

title: Simple model to understand r and g relationship
Polynomials intro
description: Polynomials are sums of terms of the form k⋅xⁿ, where k is any number and n is a positive integer. For example, 3x+2x-5 is a polynomial. Introduction to polynomials. This video covers common terminology like terms, degree, standard form, monomial, binomial and trinomial.

title: Exponential  vs. linear models
description: Given a description of a real-world relationship, determine whether that relationship is linear or exponential.

title: Exponential expressions word problems (numerical)
description: Given the description of a real-world context, we write a calculation of a certain measure. The expression is exponential because it involves repeated multiplication.

title: Bailout 1: Liquidity vs. solvency
description: Review of balance sheets.  Difference between illiquidity and insolvency.

title: Evaluating polynomials
description: Evaluating 3x²-8x+7 when x=-2.

title: Exponential expressions word problems (numerical)
description: Write exponential expressions that describe a quantity in a real-world context.

description: Simplifying the polynomial 3x²-8x+7+2x³-x²+8x-3 by combining like terms.

title: Bailout 2: Book value
description: Hypothetical bank balance sheet.  What book value means.

title: 5th roots
description: 5th roots

title: Initial value & common ratio of exponential functions
description: Get comfortable with the basic ingredients of exponential functions: the Initial value and the common ratio.

title: Adding & subtracting polynomials
description: Learn how to add and subtract polynomial expressions with one variable.

title: Bailout 3: Book value vs. market value
description: What it means when the market value of a stock is different from its book value.

title: Exponential expressions word problems (algebraic)
description: Given a real-world context that involves repeated multiplication, we model it with an exponential function.

title: Rational exponents intro
description: Learn the definition for raising a number by a fractional exponent, like 8^⅔.

description: Different ways of accounting for an asset.  Mark-to-model vs. mark-to-market.

title: Exponential expressions word problems (algebraic)
description: Write exponential expressions that model a real-world relationship.

description: What does it mean to take a number by a power which is a unit fraction? For example, what is the result of 3 raised to ½?

description: How the bank can liquidate assets to pay off debt that comes due.

title: Angles
description: Review your knowledge about angles.

title: Expand binomials
description: Use the binomial theorem in order to expand integer powers of binomial expressions.

title: Finding inverse functions
description: Learn how to find the inverses of polynomials functions, radical functions, and rational functions.

title: Domain of radical functions
description: Learn how the domain of radical functions is determined.

description: Given an exponential function that models a real-world context, we interpret it to see what each part of the function represents in the real world.

description: The bank gets bailed out by an equity infusion from a sovereign wealth fund.

description: Sal solves several problems about the equivalence of expressions with roots and rational exponents. For example, rewrite ⁶√(g⁵) as g^⅚.

description: What happens when there is no equity infusion and the bank goes in to bankruptcy.

description: Interpret the meaning of the coefficients of exponential functions in terms of the real-world relationship they model.

description: Evaluate numerical expressions with rational exponents, and convert between equivalent forms of exponential and radical expressions.

description: Learn how an exponential function behaves as the value of its input increases to positive infinity or decreases to negative infinity. Learn how to graph basic exponential functions.

description: How the banks are connected.  What happens when one bank fails.

title: Rational exponents challenge
description: Choose equivalent forms of radical and exponential expressions.

description: Analyzing the features of exponential graphs through the example of y=5ˣ.

description: What Paulson wants to do and why I don't like it.

title: Add & subtract polynomials
description: Example: Subtract -2x²+4x-1 from 6x²+3x-9.

title: Bailout 10: Moral hazard
description: Alternate plans and moral hazard.

description: In this tutorial you will rewrite variable expressions with rational exponents using the properties of exponents.

description: Why a CDO could be worth nothing even though they are "collateralized".

title: Exponential vs. linear growth over time
description: Learn how to distinguish between linear and exponential growth, and learn the differences between the end behavior of polynomial and exponential functions.

title: Exponential vs. linear growth over time
description: If we compare linear and exponential growth, we will see that over time, *any* exponential growth will surpass *any* linear growth, no matter how steep it is.

title: Properties of exponents (rational exponents)
description: Rewrite exponential expressions (where the exponent can be a fraction) using the properties of exponents.

description: Practice analyzing the end behavior of two functions that model similar real-world relationship, where one function is exponential and the other is polynomial.

description: Can the bailout work?

description: Learn how to construct exponential functions and then analyze them to model and solve real-world problems.

title: Properties of exponents challenge (rational exponents)
description: Rewrite some elaborate exponential expressions that involve fractional exponents and radicals.

description: A solution that is MUCH fairer that has a MUCH better chance of working!

description: Example: Subtract (x²+2xy-y) and (3x+5xy+2y²).

description: Evaluate elaborate expressions that contain radicals and fractional exponents.

title: Bailout 15: More on the solution
description: More on the "Plutsky Plan".

description: How to evaluate powers that are negative unit fractions, like 9 raised to -½ and 27 raised to -⅓.

description: Example: Subtract a⁴+4a²b²-2b⁴ from -3a⁴+5a^2b²+2b⁴.

title: Intro to Euclidean geometry
description:
Roughly 2400 years ago, Euclid of Alexandria wrote Elements which served as the world's geometry textbook until recently.  Studied by Abraham Lincoln in order to sharpen his mind and truly appreciate mathematical deduction, it is still the basis of what we consider a first year course in geometry.

This tutorial gives a bit of this background and then lays the conceptual foundation of points, lines, circles and planes that we will use as we journey through the world of Euclid.

title: Evaluating fractional exponents: fractional base
description: Sal shows how to evaluate (25/9)^(1/2) and (81/256)^(-1/4).

title: Euclid as the father of geometry
description: Euclid was a great mathematician and often called the father of geometry.  Learn more about Euclid and how some of our math concepts came about and how influential they have become.

title: Exponential growth & decay word problems
description: Two word problem examples: one about a radioactive decay, and the other the exponential growth of a fast-food chain.

title: Add & subtract polynomials: find the error
description: Choose which step an error was made in adding or subtracting polynomials.

title: Evaluating quotient of fractional exponents
description: Sal simplifies the complicated expression 256^(4/7) / 2^(4/7)  until he finds that the expression is equal to 16.

title: Exponential functions from tables & graphs
description: Learn how to analyze the formulas of basic exponential functions in order to find their common ratio, initial value, and other parameters.

title: Evaluating mixed radicals and exponents
description: A worked example of calculating an expression that has both a radical and an exponent. In this example, we evaluate 6^(1/2)⋅(⁵√6)³.

title: Adding and subtracting polynomials with two variables review

title: Writing exponential functions
description: Writing the exponential function whose initial value is -2 and common ratio is 1/7.

title: Evaluate radical expressions challenge
description: Evaluate numerical radical expressions using the properties of exponents.

title: Multiplying monomials
description: As an intro to more elaborate polynomial multiplication, learn how to multiply monomials (which are polynomials with a single term). For example, multiply 2x³ and 5x⁷.

title: Simplifying square roots
description: We know how to evaluate square roots of perfect squares. For example, √16=4. What about the other square roots? It's harder to give an exact number, but we can simplify them so we have a better understanding of their value. For example, √32=4⋅√2. Learn more about it in this tutorial.

title: Specifying planes in three dimensions
description: In a three-dimensional space, a plane can be defined by three points it contains, as long as those points are not on the same line. Learn more about it in this video.

title: Exponential functions from tables & graphs
description: Write exponential functions of the basic form f(x)=a⋅rˣ, either when given a table with two input-output pairs, or when given the graph of the function.

title: Multiplying monomials
description: Learn how to multiply monomials like 5x² * 4x⁶ or 4p³ * p.

title: Points, lines, and planes
description: Practice the relationship between points, lines, and planes. For example, given the drawing of a plane and points within 3D space, determine whether the points are colinear or coplanar.

title: Multiply monomials intro
description: Express the product of two monomial expressions as a single monomial

title: Writing exponential functions from graphs
description: Writing a linear function of the form f(x)=mx+b and an exponential function of the form g(x)=a⋅rˣ, given the graphs of those functions.

title: Simplifying square roots (variables)
description: A worked example of simplifying radical with a variable in it. In this example, we simplify 3√(500x³).

title: Simplify square-root expressions
description: Practice simplifying expressions with multiple radical terms.

title: Marginal revenue and marginal cost
description: Thinking about a rational quantity of juice to produce

title: More on total revenue and elasticity
description: Clarification on the relationship between total revenue and elasticity

title: Fixed, variable, and marginal cost
description: Thinking about average fixed, variable and marginal cost

title: Price discrimination
description: Charging different consumers different amounts in an attempt to optimize economic profit

title: Perfect competition and why it matters
description: Read about the economic ideal of perfect competition.

title: Consumer surplus introduction
description: Consumer surplus as difference between marginal benefit and price paid

title: Total consumer surplus as area
description: Looking at consumer surplus as area between the demand curve and the market price

title: Art terms in action
description: Watch these video demonstrations of key art terms relating to the Abstract Expressionists.

title: Taxation and dead weight loss
description: The effect of taxation on the equilibrium price and quantity

title: Geometric definitions example
description: Watch Sal solve a problem where he matches three students definition of parallel lines to a teacher's comments.

description: Sal expresses the area of a rectangle with length 4xy and width 2y as a monomial.

description: Learn to express the area of a rectangle with length 4y and width 2y as a monomial.

title: Simplifying square-root expressions
description: Worked examples of taking expressions with square roots and taking all of the perfect squares out of the square roots. For example, 2√(7x)⋅3√(14x²) can be written as 42x√(2x).

title: Analyzing graphs of exponential functions
description: Given the graph of an exponential function, Sal finds the formula of the function and a value that is outside the graph.

title: Multiplying monomials challenge
description: Sal finds the values of coefficients a and b that make (3x^a)(bx^4)=-24x^6 true for all x-values.

description: Given the graph of an exponential function with a negative initial value, Sal finds the formula of the function and solves an equation.

description: Use area to understand how to multiply monomials by polynomials.

description: Sal adds (5+2i) and (3-7i) .

title: Finding inverse functions: linear
description: Sal finds the inverses of f(x)=-x+4 and g(x)=-2x-1.

title: Advanced polynomial factorization methods
description: Learn more ways to factor polynomials with degree higher than 2.

title: Finding inverse functions: radical
description: Sal finds the inverse of h(x)=-∛(3x-6)+12.

title: Verifying that functions are inverses
description: Learn how to check whether a pair of functions are the inverses of one another.

title: Intro to Logarithms
description: Learn what logarithms are and how to evaluate them.

title: Special products of binomials
description: Learn about the special types of products of binomials: perfect squares and the difference of two squares. These will be very helpful once you tackle more advanced expressions in Algebra.

title: Rotations
description: Learn how to find the rotation that maps a given figure to another, and how to manually draw the image of a rotation.

title: Worked example: evaluating expressions using structure
description: Sal solved a few examples where we need to evaluate an expression, but we don't know the individual variable values.

title: Worked example: evaluating expressions using structure (more examples)
description: A few more examples where Sal evaluates expressions with multiple unknown variables.

title: Evaluate expressions using structure
description: Given some information about several unknown variables, evaluate an expression containing those variables.

title: Special products of the form (ax+b)(ax-b)
description: Sal expands the difference of squares (2x+8)(2x-8) as 4x²-64.

title: Factoring quadratics intro
description: Learn how to factor quadratic expressions with a leading coefficient of 1. For example, factor x²+3x+2 as (x+1)(x+2).

title: Squaring binomials of the form (ax+b)²
description: Sal expands the perfect square (7x+10)² as 49x^2+140x+100.

title: Rotating shapes
description: Sal is given a triangle on the coordinate plane and the definition of a rotation about the origin, and he manually draws the image of that rotation.

title: Special products of binomials: two variables
description: Sal finds the area of a square with side (6x-5y).

title: Rotating shapes
description: Learn how to draw the image of a given shape under a given rotation about the origin by any multiple of 90°.

title: Proof: Opposite sides of a parallelogram
description: Sal proves that a figure is a parallelogram if and only if opposite sides are congruent.

title: More examples of special products
description: Sal gives numerous examples of the two special binomial product forms: perfect squares and the difference of two squares.

title: Proof: Opposite angles of a parallelogram
description: Sal proves that opposite angles of a parallelogram are congruent.

title: Special products of binomials
description: Find special products (perfect squares and difference of squares) of "advanced" binomials: binomials with leading coefficients other than 1; binomials with higher degrees; and binomials with two variables.

title: Rotate shapes
description: Given a figure on the coordinate plane and the definition of a rotation about the origin, manually draw the image of that rotation.

title: Warmup: factoring quadratics intro
description: Acquire your quadratic factorization skills through this structured set of problems.

title: Quadrilateral angles
description: Find missing angle measures in quadrilaterals.

title: Polynomials word problems
description: See a few examples of how we can represent real-world situations with polynomials.

title: Reflections
description: Learn how to find the reflection that maps a given figure to another, and how to manually draw the image of a reflection.

title: Polynomial multiplication word problem
description: Sal finds the volume of a tank whose base has an area of 3x² + 30x + 5 square feet and whose height is 8x - 5 feet.

title: Perimeter & area
description: Perimeter is the distance around the outside of a shape. Area measures the space inside a shape. Learn how to calculate perimeter and area for various shapes.

title: Factoring quadratics by grouping
description: Learn how to factor quadratic expressions with a leading coefficient other than 1. For example, factor 2x²+7x+3 as (2x+1)(x+3).

title: Polynomial word problem: rectangle and circle area
description: Sal writes a binomial to express the difference between the area of a rectangle and the area of a circle.

title: Polynomial word problem: total value of bills
description: Sal writes a polynomial to express the total value of p twenty dollar bills, q ten dollar bills, and r five dollar bills.

title: Determining reflections (advanced)
description: Sal is given two line segments on the coordinate plane, and determines the reflection that maps one of them into the other.

title: Polynomial word problem: area of a window
description: Sal writes a polynomial expression that represents the total area of a window made of wood and glass.

title: Determine reflections (advanced)
description: Given two figures on the coordinate plane, draw the line of reflection that takes one figure to another.

title: Factoring polynomials with quadratic forms
description: Learn how to factor quadratic polynomials of the form ax^2+bx+c as the product of two linear binomials. For example, write x^2+3x-10 as (x+5)(x-2). Learn how to identify these forms in more elaborate polynomials that aren't necessarily quadratic. For example, write x^4-4x^2-12 as (x^2+2)(x^2-6).

title: Factoring quadratics: common factor + grouping
description: Sal factors 35k^2+100k-15 as 5(k+3)(7k-1).

title: Parabolas intro
description: Learn what parabolas are and about their main features: their general shape, vertex, and axis of symmetry.

title: Parabolas intro
description: Graphs of quadratic functions all have the same shape which we call "parabola." All parabolas have shared characteristics. For example, they are all symmetric about a line that passes through their vertex. This video covers this and other basic facts about parabolas.

title: Factor polynomials: quadratic methods
description: Factor polynomials that can be factored as the product of a monomial and a quadratic expression, then further factor the quadratic expression.

title: Area of a triangle on a grid
description: Learn how to calculate the area of a triangle on a grid.

title: Reflecting shapes: diagonal line of reflection
description: Sal is given two line segments on the coordinate plane and the definition of a reflection, and he draws the image of the segments under that reflection.

title: Factoring two-variable quadratics
description: Sal factors x^2+4xy-5y^2 as (x-y)(x+5y).

title: Parabolas intro
description: Make sure you understand the basic features of parabolas: vertex, axis of symmetry, intercepts, parabolas that "open up" or "open down."

title: Area of a quadrilateral on a grid
description: Learn to break up oddly shaped quadrilaterals into shapes where finding the area is more easily determined.

title: Quadratic factored form
description: The factored form of a quadratic function is an expression that is, well, factored! Like f(x)=(2x+1)(x-3). Learn how to analyze functions given in this form to find their zeros, their vertex, and their graph.

title: Rigid transformations overview
description: After studying each rigid transformation in separate, it's time to take a broader look at those transformations: which properties are preserved under which kind of transformation, and how do we map shapes using sequences of rigid transformations?

title: Factoring two-variable quadratics: rearranging
description: Sal rearranges 30x^2+11xy+y^2 as y^2+11xy+30x^2 and then factors it as (y+5x)(y+6x).

title: Areas of shapes on grids
description: Practice finding the areas of triangles and quadrilaterals on grids.

title: Zero product property
description: The zero product property states that if a⋅b=0 then either a or b equal zero. This basic property helps us solve equations like (x+2)(x-5)=0.

title: Factoring two-variable quadratics: grouping
description: Sal factors 5rs+25r-3s-15 as (s+5)(5r-3).

title: Zero product property
description: Use the zero product property to solve quadratic equations. For example, solve (x-5)(x+2)=0.

title: Perimeter & area of composite shapes
description: Sal finds perimeter and area of a non-standard polygon.

title: Factor polynomials: quadratic methods (challenge)
description: Factor "advanced" polynomials (i.e. polynomials of various degrees and or with two variables) using quadratic factorization methods.

title: Graphing quadratics in factored form
description: An example for a quadratic function in factored form is y=½(x-6)(x+2). We can analyze this form to find the x-intercepts of the graph, as well as find the vertex.

title: 401(k)s
description: 401(k)s (and how they compare to IRAs)

title: Factoring quadratics: Difference of squares
description: Learn how to factor quadratics that have the "difference of squares" form. For example, write x²-16 as (x+4)(x-4). Learn how to identify this form in more elaborate expressions. For example, write 4x²-49 as (2x+7)(2x-7).

title: Warmup: graphing quadratics in factored form
description: Make sure you know how to graph quadratic functions that are given in the factored form f(x)=(x+a)(x+b), as a warmup to our exercise.

title: Challenge problems: perimeter & area
description: Three example problems involving perimeter and area.

title: Difference of squares intro
description: When an expression can be viewed as the difference of two perfect squares, i.e. a²-b², then we can factor it as (a+b)(a-b). For example, x²-25 can be factored as (x+5)(x-5). This method is based on the pattern (a+b)(a-b)=a²-b², which can be verified by expanding the parentheses in (a+b)(a-b).

title: Graph quadratics in factored form
description: Graph quadratic functions that are given in factored form. For example, graph y=(x-4)(x+2).

title: Dilations
description:
In addition to the three rigid transformation, there are the dilations, which expand or shrink figures while keeping the same proportions. These are extremely important in the subject of Similarity!

Gain experience by performing dilation, learn how to find the dilation that maps a given figure to another, and learn how to manually draw the image of a dilation.

title: Quadratic word problems (factored form)
description: Solving a problem where a quadratic function (given in factored form) models the height of a launched rocket.

title: Quadratic word problems (factored form)
description: Solve real-world word problems that involve quadratic models. In this exercise, that models are given in factored form.

title: Solving quadratics by taking square roots
description: In this tutorial you will learn about the most basic way of solving quadratic equations.

title: Solving quadratics by taking square roots
description: Sal solves the equation 2x^2+3=75 by isolating x^2 and taking the square root of both sides.

title: Solving quadratics by taking square roots
description: Learn how to solve quadratic equations like x^2=36 or (x-2)^2=49.

title: Factoring quadratics: Perfect squares
description: Learn how to factor quadratics that have the "perfect square" form. For example, write x²+6x+9 as (x+3)². Learn how to identify these forms in more elaborate expressions. For example, write 4x²+28x+49 as (2x+7)².

title: Area of a circle intuition
description: Using triangles to create an informal argument for the area of a circle formula.

title: Quadratics by taking square roots intro
description: Solve simple quadratic equations by taking the square root of both sides of the equation.

title: Perfect square factorization intro
description: When an expression has the general form a²+2ab+b², then we can factor it as (a+b)². For example, x²+10x+25 can be factored as (x+5)². This method is based on the pattern (a+b)²=a²+2ab+b², which can be verified by expanding the parentheses in (a+b)(a+b).

title: Solving quadratics by taking square roots examples
description: Sal solves the equation (x+3)²-4=0 and finds the x-intercepts of f(x)=(x-2)²-9.

title: Perfect squares intro
description: Factor quadratic expressions into the special products of the general form (x+a)² or (x-a)².

title: Quadratics by taking square roots
description: Solve quadratic equations of the form (x+a)²-b=0. These can be solved using square roots. For example, solve (x-5)²-4=0.

title: Solving quadratics by taking square roots: strategy
description: Sal discusses the exact order of steps in the process of solving the equation 3(x+6)^2=75.

title: Properties & definitions of transformations
description: Let's continue our deep voyage through the world of transformations! Use your knowledge about the precise descriptions of the rigid transformations and their properties in various situations.

title: Quadratics by taking square roots: strategy
description: Analyze the process of solving a quadratic equation by taking the square root.

title: Sequences of transformations
description: Determining whether segment lengths and angle measures are preserved under a given sequence of transformations.

title: Sequences of transformations
description: Given a description of a sequence of transformations, determine whether it preserves segment length or angle measure.

title: Quadratics by taking square roots: with steps
description: Sal analyzes a given solution of a quadratic equation, and finds where and what was the error in that process.

title: Transformations & congruence
description: Two figures are congruent if you can go from one to another through some combination of translations, reflections and rotations.  In this tutorial, we'll really internalize this by working through the actual transformations.

title: Quadratics by taking square roots: with steps
description: Give a detailed solution of quadratic equations.

title: Defining transformations
description: Given a description of the effect of a certain transformation, we determine whether that transformation is a translation, a rotation, or a reflection.

title: Solving simple quadratics review
description: Simple quadratic equations like x^2=4 can be solved by taking the square root. This article reviews several examples and gives you a chance to practice on your own.

title: Precisely defining rotations
description: Read a dialog where a student and a teacher work towards defining rotations as precisely as possible.

title: Strategy in factoring quadratics
description: There are a lot of methods to factor quadratics, which apply on different occasions and conditions. Now that we know all of them, let's think strategically about which of them is useful for a given quadratic expression we want to factor.

title: Triangle congruence
description: Learn how the definition of congruence using rigid transformations can be simplified to simple criteria when studying congruent triangles.

title: Quadratic vertex form
description: The vertex form of a quadratic function shows the coordinates of the parabola's vertex. For example, the vertex of g(x)=(x-1)²+2 is at (1,2). Learn how to analyze functions given in this form to find their zeros, their vertex, and their graph.

title: Defining transformations
description: Given a description of the effect of a transformation, determine which rigid transformation it is.

title: Congruent triangles & the SSS postulate/criterion
description: Sal explains what it means for triangles to be congruent and what is a postulate/axiom. He also presents the SSS congruence postulate/criterion and its justification.

title: Strategy in factoring quadratics (part 1 of 2)
description: There are a lot of methods to factor quadratics, which apply on different occasions and conditions. After learning all of them in separate, let's think strategically about which method is useful for a given quadratic expression we want to factor.

title: Vertex form introduction
description: One of the common forms for quadratic functions is called vertex form, because it highlights the coordinates of the vertex of the function's graph.

title: Triangle congruence postulates/criteria
description: Sal introduces and justifies the SSS, SAS, ASA and AAS postulates for congruent triangles. He also shows that AAA is only good for similarity. For SSA, better to watch next video.

title: Strategy in factoring quadratics (part 2 of 2)
description: There are a lot of methods to factor quadratics, which apply on different occasions and conditions. After learning all of them in separate, let's think strategically about which method is useful for a given quadratic expression we want to factor.

title: Graphing quadratics: vertex form
description: Learn how to graph any quadratic function that is given in vertex form. Here, Sal graphs y=-2(x-2)²+5.

title: Why SSA isn't a congruence postulate/criterion
description: There are some cases when SSA can imply triangle congruence, but not always. This is why it's not like the other triangle congruence postulates/criteria.

title: Proofs with transformations
description: Explore different ways of proving some theorems about lines and angles. Some transformations are used.

title: Warmup: graphing quadratics in vertex form
description: Make sure you know how to graph quadratic functions that are given in vertex form f(x)=k(x-a)²+b, as a warmup to our exercise.

title: Factoring polynomials with special product forms
description: Factor polynomials of various degrees using factorization methods that are based on the special product forms "difference of squares" and "perfect squares." For example, factor 25x⁴-30x²+9 as (5x²-3)².

title: Determining congruent triangles
description: Sal uses the SSS, ASA, SAS, and AAS postulates to find congruent triangles.

title: Identifying type of transformation
description: Sal is given information about a transformation in terms of a few pairs of points and their corresponding images, and he determines what kind of transformation it can be.

title: Factoring perfect squares: 4th degree polynomial
description: Sal factors 25x^4-30x^2+9 as (5x^2-3)^2.

title: Graph quadratics in vertex form
description: Graph quadratic functions that are given in the vertex form a(x+b)²+c. For example, graph y=-2(x-2)²+5.

title: Determine congruent triangles
description: Use the triangle congruence criteria SSS, SAS, ASA, and AAS to determine that two triangles are congruent.

title: Symmetry
description: Learn about different kinds of symmetries of two-dimensional shapes, and analyze various shapes according to their symmetries.

title: Factoring difference of squares: two variables
description: If we expand (a+b)(a-b) we will get a²-b². Factorization goes the other way: suppose we have an expression that is the difference of two squares, like x²-25 or 49x²-y², then we can factor is using the roots of those squares. For example, x²-25 can be factored as (x+5)(x-5). This is an extremely useful method that is used throughout math.

title: Quadratic word problems (vertex form)
description: Solve real-world word problems that involve quadratic models. In this exercise, that models are given in vertex form.

title: Finding angles in isosceles triangles (example 2)
description: Sal combines what we know about isosceles triangles and parallel lines with the power of algebra to solve the angles of an isosceles triangle.

title: Proof: Rhombus area
description: Sal proves that we can find the area of a rhombus by taking half the product of the lengths of the diagonals.

title: Geometric constructions: perpendicular line
description: Sal constructs a line perpendicular to a given line using compass and straightedge.

title: Solid geometry word problems
description: Solve problems concerning real-world situations with the volumes of cones, cylinders, and spheres.

title: Graphing quadratics: standard form
description: Learn how to graph any quadratic function that is given in standard form. Here, Sal graphs y=5x²-20x+15.

title: Dividing line segments
description: Watch Sal figure out the coordinates of a point between two other points that give a certain ratio.

title: Trigonometric ratios in right triangles
description: Learn how to find the sine, cosine, and tangent of angles in right triangles.

title: Finding arc measures with equations
description: Sal solves a few items where arc measures are given in equations, we have to find a variable, then use it to find an arc measure.

title: Scale & reflect parabolas
description: We can make parabolas wider or narrower, and we can reflect them over the $x$-axis. Practice how this is done, graphically and algebraically.

title: Writing equations of perpendicular lines (example 2)
description: Sal finds the equation of a line perpendicular to a line given in slope-intercept form that passes through a specific point.

title: Solving for a side with the law of sines
description: Sal is given a triangle with two angle measures and one side length, and he finds all the missing side lengths and angle measures using the law of sines.

title: 2. The Big Bang
description: Big History will introduce you to many new ideas and claims. You won’t simply accept these claims as facts and move on. You’ll be encouraged to test them. You’ll learn how to evaluate information presented to you, and be encouraged to decide for yourself what to believe and what to investigate further. This is how our thinking advances. Today’s scientific view of the history of the Universe is based on the work of thousands of scientists and scholars over thousands of years. People built upon each other’s work. New technology and new observations have led to ever sharper theories about the Universe and its beginnings. As you study how these views have evolved, you’ll develop your own skills for testing the claims of others and making claims of your own.

title: Inscribed shapes: find inscribed angle
description: Using either the inscribed angle theorem or the fact that two inscribed angles that intercept the same arc must be congruent.

title: Proof: perpendicular radius bisects chord
description: Simple proof using RSH postulate to show that a radius perpendicular to a chord bisects it

title: Intro to rotational symmetry
description: Sal checks whether various figure are symmetrical under a 180 degrees rotation.

title: Sums and products of rational and irrational numbers
description: Determine whether various combinations of rational and irrational numbers are rational or irrational themselves.

title: Triangle similarity review
description: Review the triangle similarity criteria and use them to determine similar triangles.

title: The quadratic formula
description: With the quadratic formula, we can solve any quadratic equation! Learn how to use it with an example.

title: Geometry word problem: Earth & Moon radii
description: Similarity and the Golden ratio join forces again, this time to save the Earth! (Or maybe just finding its radius)

title: Midpoint formula
description: Walk through writing a general formula for the midpoint between two points.

title: Worked examples: Forms & features of quadratic functions
description: Choosing whether factored form, vertex form or standard form of a quadratic is best in different situations.

title: Points inside/outside/on a circle
description: Given the center and radius of a circle, determine if a point is inside of the circle, on the circle, or outside of the circle

title: Intro to parabola transformations
description: Sal discusses how we can shift and scale the graph of a parabola to obtain any other parabola, and how this affects the equation of the parabola.

title: Right triangle word problems
description: Solve word problems by modeling real-world (and not-so-real) situations as right triangles and using trigonometry.

title: Degrees to radians
description: Sal converts the degree measures 150° and -45° to radians.

title: Art conservation
description: Art conservators protect and preserve artwork for future generations to enjoy. Go behind-the-scenes at the Asian Art Museum and learn more about their work.

title: Manuscripts
description: Learn about medieval and Renaissance manuscripts, and how these exquisite handmade objects were created and used.

title: Tangents of circles problem (example 1)
description: Sal finds missing angles using the property that tangents are perpendicular to the radius.

title: Tangents of circles problem (example 2)
description: Sal finds a missing angle using the property that tangents are perpendicular to the radius.

title: Indifference curves and marginal rate of substitution
description: We can graph how we value tradeoffs between two goods

title: Optimal point on budget line
description: Using indifference curves to think about the point on the budget line that maximizes total utility

title: Factoring difference of squares: two variables (example 2)
description: Sal factors 49x^2-49y^2 as (7x+7y)(7x-7y) or as 49(x+y)(x-y).

title: Completing the square
description: You're already familiar with factoring quadratics, but have begun to realize that it only is useful in certain cases.  Well, this tutorial will introduce you to something far more powerful and general.  Even better, it is the bridge to understanding and proving the famous quadratic formula.

title: Completing the square (intermediate)
description: Solve quadratic equations of the form x^2+bx+c by completing the square.

title: Using the angle bisector theorem
description: Sal uses the angle bisector theorem to solve for sides of a triangle.

title: Number of solutions of quadratic equations
description: Analyze quadratic equations in order to determine how many different real number solutions they have.

title: Rotating 2D shapes in 3D
description: If you rotate a 2D shape about an axis, the shape will define a 3D object. Watch Sal rotating various 2D shapes and see what 3D objects he gets!

title: Masterpieces old and new
description: Discover what makes a masterpiece by learning how classical works are composed. Music Director Gerard Schwarz explains the history, context and compositional techniques behind famous orchestral works, from Beethoven to leading composers of the present day.

title: Proof: all circles are similar
description: Watch Sal informally prove that all circles are similar by showing how we can translate then dilate any circle onto another.

title: Intro to inverse trig functions
description: Learn about arcsine, arccosine, and arctangent, and how they can be used to solve for a missing angle in right triangles.

title: Parallel lines from equation (example 3)
description: Sal determines which pairs out of a few given linear equations are parallel.

title: Sine & cosine of complementary angles
description: Learn about the relationship between the sine of an angle and the cosine of its complementary angle, which is the angle that completes to 90°.

title: Radians & arc length
description: Solve problems related to radians and arc length like finding an arc length given the central angle and radius.

title: Solving for an angle with the law of cosines
description: Sal is given a triangle with all side lengths but no angle measure, and he finds one of the angle measures using the law of cosines.

title: 7. Agriculture & Civilization
description: If everyone had to survive as foragers, there wouldn't be nearly enough food to feed 7 billion people. Farming sustains us, and it's easy to assume it has always existed, but it hasn't. Humans invented agriculture. This altered our relationship with the Earth, drove population growth, and enabled the emergence of magnificent civilizations.

title: Theorems concerning triangle properties
description: Now that we know how to show that two triangles are congruent, let's put that to use by proving some theorems about triangles.

title: Theorems concerning quadrilateral properties
description: Triangle congruence is not only useful when working with triangles, it's also useful with any other kind of polygon! Prove a few theorems about the properties of parallelograms using triangle congruence.

title: Rational vs. irrational expressions
description: Determine whether an expression that is the combination of two rational/irrational numbers is rational or irrational itself.

title: Understanding the quadratic formula
description: Gain more insight into the quadratic formula and how it is used in quadratic equations.

title: Introduction to the Pythagorean theorem
description: Right triangles and the Pythagorean Theorem

title: Special right triangles intro (part 2)
description: A few more 45-45-90 triangle examples and an introduction to 30-60-90 triangles.

title: Features of quadratic functions: strategy
description: Identify the form of a quadratic function that immediately reveals a given feature of that function. Features in question are the y-intercept of the graph, the zeroes ("roots") of the function, and the vertex of the parabola.

title: Trigonometric ratios in right triangles
description: Given the side lengths of a right triangle, find the sine, cosine, or tangent of one of the acute angles.

title: Inscribed angles
description: We'll now dig a bit deeper in our understanding of circles by looking at inscribed angles and related properties.

title: Budget line
description: What I can buy with my income

title: Breakdown of gas prices
description: Where the dollars at the pump go

title: Solving exponential models
description: Learn how to solve word problems that require exponential equations.

title: Solving general triangles
description: Use the power of trigonometry in order to solve various problems that involve triangles.

title: The Pythagorean identity
description: Prove the Pythagorean trigonometric identity for all real numbers and use it in order to solve problems.

title: Calculating state taxes and take home pay
Depreciation in cash flow
description: Depreciation in Cash Flow

title: Call option as leverage
description: Call Option as Leverage

title: Put payoff diagram
description: Put Payoff Diagram

title: Solving quadratics by factoring
description: In this tutorial, you'll learn some pretty elaborate ways of solving quadratic equations, by harnessing the mighty strength of algebra.

title: Introduction to triangle similarity
description: In this tutorial, we will use what we learned about similarity of polygons in the specific case of triangles. We will come up with specific conditions for triangles to be similar, and use them to determine whether two triangles are similar.

title: Proofs of general theorems that use triangle congruence
description: Gain even more experience with using triangle congruence in proofs.

title: Solve triangles: angle bisector theorem
description: Use the angle bisector theorem to find missing side lengths in triangles.

title: Geometry word problem: a perfect pool shot
description: Sal uses triangle similarity to plan the perfect shot in a pool game.

title: Graph quadratics in standard form
description: Graph quadratic functions given in the standard form ax²+bx+c. For example, graph y=5x²-20x+15.

title: Divide line segments
description: Figure out the coordinates of a point between two other points that give a certain ratio. For example, find a point C so that it is two thirds of the way between point A and B.

title: Challenge problem: Points on two circles
description: Watch Sal solve a challenging problem where he has to determine if points are on both, one, or neither of two circles.

title: Parallel & perpendicular lines from graph
description: The slopes of parallel lines are equal, and the slopes of perpendicular lines are opposite reciprocals. This is a worked example of determining whether given lines are parallel or perpendicular.

title: Challenge problems: Arc length 1
description: Solve four challenging problems that ask you to find arc length without directly giving you the arc measure.

title: China
description: Explore the arts and belief systems of China.

title: The founding documents of the United States of America
description: There wasn’t any email or SMS in the 1700s when the founders of America sent letters and drafted the documents that became the blueprint for American democracy. The documents of the founding of America tell the story of issues being grappled with and personalities discussing moral and ideological differences.

title: Long term supply curve
description: The supply curve can be different on longer time scales as the market gets time to adjust

title: Paintings
description: Learn about paintings and portraits, and discover the techniques used by the artists who made them.

title: Tangents of circles problems
description: Solve problems related to tangents of circles.

title: Drawings
description: Learn about the art of drawing as revealed through the work of several masters.

title: More on elasticity of demand
description: Looking a bit deeper at why elasticity changes despite having a linear demand curve

title: Marginal revenue below average total cost
description: Why it is rational to produce at a loss

title: Finding a quadrilateral from its symmetries
description: Two of the points that define a certain quadrilateral are (0,9) and (3,4). The quadrilateral has reflective symmetry over the line y=3-x. Draw and classify the quadrilateral.

title: Proof: sum & product of two rationals is rational
description: Sal proves that the sum, or the product, of any two rational numbers will always be a rational number.

title: Geometry proof problem: midpoint
description: Sal proves that a point is the midpoint of a segment using triangle congruence.

title: Geometric constructions: angle bisector
description: Sal constructs a line that bisects a given angle using compass and straightedge.

title: Density
description: Use your knowledge of surface area and volume to solve problems involving density.

title: Midpoint formula
description: Find the midpoint of a segment on the coordinate plane, or find the endpoint of a segment given one point and the midpoint.

title: Comparing features of quadratic functions
description: Sal compares the y-intercepts, the zeros, and the concavity of quadratic functions given graphically and algebraically.

title: Arc measure with equations
description: Use the fact that the arc measures of a circle must sum to 360 degrees to find missing arc measures by setting up equations.

title: Right triangle trigonometry review
description: Review right triangle trigonometry and how to use it to solve problems.

title: Radians to degrees
description: Sal converts the radian measures π and -π/3 to degrees.

title: Solving for an angle with the law of sines
description: Sal is given a triangle with two side lengths and one angle measure, and he finds all the missing angle measures using the law of sines.

title: Area of inscribed equilateral triangle
description: A worked example of finding the area of an equilateral triangle inscribed within a circle who's area is known. This video uses Heron's formula and some trigonometry.

title: Determining tangent lines: angles
description: Solve two problems that apply properties of tangents to determine if a line is tangent to a circle.

title: Art conservation
description: Go behind-the-scenes and learn about art conservation.

title: Market equilibrium
description: The actual price you see in the world is a balancing act between supply and demand.

title: Tangents of circles problem (example 3)
description: Sal finds a missing length using the property that tangents are perpendicular to the radius.

title: Topic C: Lesson 25: Properties of matrix multiplication
Factor polynomials: special product forms
description: Factor "advanced" polynomials (i.e. polynomials of various degrees and or with two variables) using special product factorization methods.

title: Completing the square
description: Some quadratic expressions can be factored as perfect squares. For example, x²+6x+9=(x+3)². However, even if an expression isn't a perfect square, we can turn it into one by adding a constant number. For example, x²+6x+5 isn't a perfect square, but if we add 4 we get (x+3)². This, in essence, is the method of *completing the square*

title: Solving similar triangles
description: Learn how to find missing measures of triangles using the fact that they are similar to other triangles.

title: Pythagorean theorem
description:
Named after the Greek philosopher who lived nearly 2600 years ago, the Pythagorean theorem is as good as math theorems get (Pythagoras also started a religious movement).  It's simple.  It's beautiful.  It's powerful.

In this tutorial, we will cover what it is and how it can be used.  We have another tutorial that gives you as many proofs of it as you might need.

title: Proof of the quadratic formula
description: Sal proves the quadratic formula using the method of completing the square.

title: Special right triangles
description: Use your knowledge of 30-60-90 and 45-45-90 triangles to solve some problems.

title: Instruments of the orchestra
description: Learn about the different instruments of the orchestra as they are presented and demonstrated by  principal players from famous symphony orchestras.

title: Arc measure
description: Arc measure is equal to the arc's central angle. We'll explore this fact and solve some problems related to it.

title: Shifting parabolas
description: The graph of y=(x-k)²+h is the resulting of shifting (or translating) the graph of y=x², k units to the right and h units up. For example, y=(x-3)²-4 is the result of shifting y=x² 3 units to the right and -4 units up, which is the same as 4 units down.

title: Challenge problems: Arc length 2
description: Solve two challenging problems that ask you to find an arc measure using the arc length.

title: Write equations of parallel & perpendicular lines
description: Write the equation for a line that is a parallel or perpendicular to a line given in slope-intercept form and goes through a specific point.

title: Challenge problems: Arc length (radians) 1
description: Solve three challenging problems that ask you to find arc length without directly giving you the arc measure.

title: 3. Stars & Elements
description: By 200 million years after the Big Bang, the Universe had become a very dark and cold place. Then things started to change. First, galaxies and nebulae formed. These were the earliest structures in the Universe. Then stars – “hot spots” of light and energy – emerged from these clouds of dust and gas. Why did they form and how did they change everything? Stars, the first complex, stable entities in the Universe, have the capacity to generate energy for millions, even billions of years. The first stars, which passed through their entire life cycles relatively quickly, produced many of the chemical elements of the periodic table. In this unit, you’ll learn how stars first formed and how the lives and deaths of stars provided the chemical diversity necessary for even more complex things.

title: Production possibilities frontier
description: This tutorial goes back to the basics.  You are a hunter-gatherer with only so much time to hunt or gather.  How do you allocate your time and energy to maximize your happiness?  This is what we try to understand through our study of the production possibilities frontier and opportunity cost.

title: Proofs concerning isosceles triangles
description: Sal proves that the base angles in isosceles triangles are congruent, and conversely, that triangles with congruent base angles are isosceles. He also proves that the perpendicular to the base of an isosceles triangle bisects it.

title: Proof: Diagonals of a parallelogram
description: Sal proves that a quadrilateral is a parallelogram if and only if its diagonals bisect each other.

title: Proofs concerning irrational numbers
description: Learn some proofs about the existence of irrational numbers.

title: Using the quadratic formula
description: Sal solves the equation -7q^2+2q+9=0 by using the quadratic formula.

title: Density word problem: blimp
description: Sal solves a word problem about the number of passengers a blimp can carry, using his knowledge of volume and density.

title: Rotate 2D shapes in 3D
description: Practice your 3D visualization skills by rotating 2D shapes.

title: Vertex & axis of symmetry of a parabola
description: Sal rewrites a quadratic equation in vertex form and shows how it reveals the vertex of the corresponding parabola.

title: Solving for a side in a right triangle using the trigonometric ratios
description: Learn how to find a side length in a right triangle when given one side length and one acute angle.

title: Solve for an angle in right triangles
description: Given two sides in a right triangle, find one of the acute angles using trigonometry.

title: Perpendicular lines from equation
description: Sal determines which pairs out of a few given linear equations are perpendicular.

title: Sine & cosine of complementary angles
description: Sal shows that the sine of any angle is equal to the cosine of its complementary angle.

title: The founding fathers of the United States of America
description: From the variety of personalities of the founding fathers to the issue of slavery and representative democracy, the early days of the United States of America were filled with debate and compromise and the building blocks of a democracy that survives today.

title: Solve triangles using the law of cosines
description: Solve missing triangle measures using the law of cosines.

title: Inscribed angle theorem proof
description: Proving that an inscribed angle is half of a central angle that subtends the same arc.

title: Africa
description: The diverse cultural life of Africa has been expressed through everyday objects and unique works of art since ancient times. The Museum’s collection of over 200,000 African items encompasses archaeological and contemporary material from across the continent.

title: Finding a quadrilateral from its symmetries (example 2)
description: Two of the points that define a certain quadrilateral are (-4,-2) and (0,5). The quadrilateral has a reflective symmetry over the lines y=x/2 and y=-2x+5. Draw and classify the quadrilateral.

title: Solving quadratics by completing the square
description: For example, solve x²+6x=-2 by manipulating it into (x+3)²=7 and then taking the square root.

title: Worked example: completing the square (leading coefficient ≠ 1)
description: Sal solves the equation 4x^2+40x-300=0 by completing the square.

title: Solving problems with similar & congruent triangles
description: You already saw how we can use similarity and congruence to find missing measures in triangles. Let's do the same now to solve more kinds of polygons, and more challenging problems!

title: Pythagorean theorem II
description: More Pythagorean Theorem examples. Introduction to 45-45-90 triangles.

title: Quadratic word problem: ball
description: Sal solves a word problem about a ball being shot in the air. The equation for the height of the ball as a function of time is quadratic.

title: Problem solving with distance on the coordinate plane
description: Use what you know about distance to solve problems on the coordinate plan like finding the perimeter of a shape or determining if a point is on a circle.

title: Coordinate plane word problem
description: Watch Sal solve an example where has to determine which of the Minions a wizard can reach using the coordinate plane.

title: Parallel & perpendicular lines from graph
description: Given points that two lines go through or the graph of each line, classify the lines as parallel, perpendicular, or neither.

title: Introduction to radians
description: Most people know that you can measure angles with degrees, but only exceptionally worldly people know that radians can be an exciting alternative. As you'll see, degrees are somewhat arbitrary.

title: Korea
description: Discover the arts and belief systems of Korea.

title: Solve triangles using the law of sines
description: Solve missing triangle measures using the law of sines.

title: Inscribed angles
description: Sal finds a missing inscribed angle using the inscribed angle theorem.

title: 8. Expansion & Interconnection
description: Early humans had pretty small social networks. At most, they probably met only a couple hundred people who probably all lived very similar lives to their own. As people started farming, these networks got larger. People were increasingly specialized in their work and trade. Populations in cities got larger. Trade reached across longer distances, bringing together people with very different lives and ways of thinking.

title: The demand curve
description: You've probably heard of supply and demand.  Well, this tutorial focuses on the demand part.  All else equal, do people want more or less of something if the price goes down (what would you do)? Not only will you get an intuition for the way we typically depict a demand curve, you'll get an understanding for what might shift it.

title: The Middle East
description: The museum's collection covers the civilizations and cultures of the Middle East from the Neolithic period until the present. The Islamic collection includes archaeological assemblages from Iraq, Iran and Egypt as well as collections of inlaid metalwork from medieval Iran, Syria and Egypt and Iznik ceramics from Turkey.

title: Factoring polynomials challenge
description: Review your skills for using the structure of expressions with some challenge problems.

title: Proof: product of rational & irrational is irrational
description: The product of any rational number and any irrational number will always be an irrational number. This allows us to quickly conclude that 3π is irrational.

title: Proof: √2 is irrational
description: Sal proves that the square root of 2 is an irrational number, i.e. it cannot be given as the ratio of two integers.

title: Worked example: quadratic formula
description: Solving 6x²+3=2x-6 by rewriting in standard form and identifying the parameters a, b, and c, that can be used within the quadratic formula.

title: Density word problems
description: Solve problems concerning real-world situations using your knowledge of volume, surface area, and density.

title: 30-60-90 triangle example problem
description: Using what we know about 30-60-90 triangles to solve what at first seems to be a challenging problem

title: Introduction to the trigonometric ratios
description: Learn what sine, cosine, and tangent are.

title: Comparing maximum points of quadratic functions
description: Given several quadratic functions represented in different forms, Sal finds the one with the lowest maximum value.

title: Arc length (degrees)
description: Think about the relationship between central angle and arc length. This tutorial uses degrees not radians.

title: Trigonometric ratios & similarity
description: Learn how the trigonometric ratios are derived from triangle similarity considerations.

title: Radians & degrees
description: Convert angle measures given in degrees to radians and vice versa.

title: The founding mothers of the United States of America
description: The term "founding fathers" is synonymous with the American Revolution and the founding of the United States of America, however, there were women who played an important role in the founding as well.  Journalist Cokie Roberts explores the role of women in America's founding and discusses with Aspen Institute President and CEO Walter Isaacson America's "Founding Mothers."

title: General triangle word problems
description: Solve word problems that involve general triangles using trigonometry.

title: The supply curve
description: Now we'll focus on the "supply" part of supply and demand.  Supply curves (as we typically depict them) come out of the idea that producers will make more if they get paid more.

title: Short-run oil prices
description: Thinking about what moves oil prices

title: Features of a circle from its standard equation
description: Find the center and radius of a circle given the equation in standard form.

title: Proofs concerning equilateral triangles
description: Sal proves that the angles of an equilateral triangle are all congruent (and therefore they all measure 60°), and conversely, that triangles with all congruent angles are equilateral.

title: Worked example: Completing the square (intro)
description: Sal completes x²-44x into a perfect square.

title: Completing the square
description: Solve quadratic equations of the form ax^2+bx+c by completing the square.

title: Using similar & congruent triangles
description: Sal uses the similarity of triangles and the congruence of others in this multi-step problem to find the area of a polygon.

title: Quadratic formula review
description: The quadratic formula allows us to solve any quadratic equation that's in the form ax^2 + bx + c = 0. This article reviews how to apply the formula.

title: Midpoint formula review
description: Review the midpoint formula and how to apply it to solve problems.

title: Area of trapezoid on the coordinate plane
description: Sal finds the area of a trapezoid using the distance formula and the trapezoid area formula.

title: Intro to arc measure
description: Sal introduces arc measure including that they must sum to 360, conventions of minor and major arcs, and a comparison to arc length.

title: Shift parabolas
description: We can shift a parabola by moving it up, down, left, or right. Practice how this is expressed graphically and algebraically.

title: Intro to radians
description: Sal explains the definition and motivation for radians and the relationship between radians and degrees.

title: Proof: parallel lines have the same slope
description: Sal proves that parallel lines have the same slope using triangle similarity.

title: Challenge problems: Arc length (radians) 2
description: Solve two challenging problems that ask you to find an arc measure using the arc length.

title: 4. Our Solar System & Earth
description: Billowing clouds of matter spun around and around our young Sun, gradually forming just about everything in our Solar System – from meteors and asteroids to all the planets and moons. One planet in particular would enable the creation of even more remarkable complexity.

title: Inscribed shapes problem solving
description: Use properties of inscribed angles to prove properties of inscribed shapes, then apply these properties some fun problem solving!

title: Comparative advantage and gains from trade
description:
Should you try to produce everything yourself or only what you are best at and trade for everything else?  What if you're better than your trading partners at everything?  

This tutorial focuses on comparative advantage, specialization and gains from trade with a microeconomic lens.

title: Symmetry of 2D shapes
description: Analyze various shapes according to their reflective and rotational symmetries.

title: Proof: sum of rational & irrational is irrational
description: The sum of any rational number and any irrational number will always be an irrational number. This allows us to quickly conclude that ½+√2 is irrational.

title: Geometry proof problem: congruent segments
description: Sal proves that two pairs of segments are congruent using the ASA and AAS congruence criteria.

title: Solid geometry intro
description: Tired of perimeter and area and now want to measure 3-D space-take-upness.  Well you've found the right tutorial.  Enjoy!

title: Pythagorean theorem proofs
description: The Pythagorean theorem is one of the most famous ideas in all of mathematics.  This tutorial proves it.  Then proves it again... and again... and again.  More than just satisfying any skepticism of whether the Pythagorean theorem is really true (only one proof would be sufficient for that), it will hopefully open your mind to new and beautiful ways to prove something very powerful.

title: Quadratic word problems (standard form)
description: Solve real-world word problems that involve quadratic models. In this exercise, that models are given in standard form.

title: Finding features of quadratic functions
description: Sal finds the zeros, the vertex, & the line of symmetry of quadratic functions given in vertex form, factored form, & standard form.

title: Solving for a side in right triangles with trigonometry
description: Sal is given a right triangle with an acute angle of 65° and a leg of 5 units, and he uses trigonometry to find the two missing sides.

title: Modeling with right triangles
description: Solve real-world problems that can be modeled by right triangles, using trigonometry.

title: Overview
description: Explore the question, "What is Asia?" and peek behind-the-scenes at the Asian Art Museum.

title: Using complementary angles
description: Sal solved the following problem: Given that cos(58°)=0.53, find sin(32°).

title: Proof of the law of sines
description: Sal gives a simple proof of the Law of sines.

title: Introduction to economics
description: This tutorial (that only has one video) is an overview of what economics is.  In particular it will tell you the difference between microeconomics (the subject you're in right now) and macroeconomics.  Really good first watch to give you some context on the world of economics.

title: 9. Acceleration
description: Just 500 years ago, humans lived in four separate world zones, each with distinct cultures and technologies. Now, humanity is linked within one interconnected network of information and commerce that spans the entire planet.

title: Inscribed shapes
description: Find missing angles and lengths in inscribed shapes.

title: Proof: radius is perpendicular to a chord it bisects
description: Sal proves that if a radius in a circle is drawn so it bisects a chord, then the radius is also perpendicular to that chord. The proof uses SSS congruence.

title: Properties of tangents
description: Explore, prove, and apply properties of circles that involve tangents.

title: Working with triangles
description: Learn how to solve different geometric problems using triangle congruence.

title: Proof: The diagonals of a kite are perpendicular
description: Sal proves that the diagonals of a kite are perpendicular, by using the SSS and SAS triangle congruence criteria.

title: Solving quadratics by completing the square: no solution
description: Sal solves the equation 4x^2+40x+280=0 by completing the square, only to find there's no solution for this equation.

title: Worked example: quadratic formula (example 2)
description: Sal solves the equation -x^2+8x=1 by first bringing it to standard form and then using the quadratic formula.

title: Distance and midpoints
