description: Find the distance between two points or the midpoint of two points.

title: Special right triangles proof (part 1)
description: Learn how to prove the ratios between the sides of a 30-60-90 triangle.

title: Intro to the trigonometric ratios
description: Sal introduces sine, cosine, and tangent, and gives an example of finding them for a given right triangle.

title: Coordinate plane word problems: polygons
description: Solve all sorts of word problems with crazy contexts that use polygons on the coordinate plane.

title: Arc length from subtended angle
description: Finding the length of an arc using the degree of the angle subtended by the arc and the perimeter of the circle.

title: Parallel & perpendicular lines from equation
description: Use your knowledge about the slopes of parallel and perpendicular lines to solve some problems. For example, what's the equation of the line perpendicular to y=3x-3 and passes through the point (-8, -2).

title: Arc length (radians)
description: Think about the relationships between arc measures, central angles, and arc length in radians.

title: Civil liberties, privacy, and the Constitution
description: Does the widespread availability of personal data justify the government’s need for covert surveillance or does it make secrecy obsolete and unnecessary? Recent disclosures by Snowden, Manning, and WikiLeaks have redefined the debate about the proper balance between privacy and transparency.  Hear from experts with different perspectives on the subject.

title: Proof of the law of cosines
description: Sal gives a simple proof of the Law of cosines.

title: Laws of sines and cosines review
description: Review the law of sines and the law of cosines, and use them to solve problems with any triangle.

title: The Americas
description: The British Museum holds thousands of objects from the Americas. Discover the Nazca and Inca peoples, the ancient Mayan city of Yaxchilian and Aztec turquoise mosaics. The collection of The British Museum also explores the art of the Native inhabitants of Canada and the United States, while illustrating the effect of European contact and colonization on their communities.

title: Corresponding angles in congruent triangles
description: We write the letters of congruent triangles so their order tells us which parts are corresponding. In this video, Sal uses this notation to solve some angles.

title: Sums and products of irrational numbers
description: The sum of two irrational numbers can be rational and it can be irrational. It depends on which irrational numbers we're talking about exactly. The same goes for products for two irrational numbers. This video covers this fact with various examples.

title: Proof: square roots of prime numbers are irrational
description: Sal proves that the square root of any prime number must be an irrational number. For example, because of this proof we can quickly determine that √3, √5, √7, or √11 are irrational numbers.

title: Use similar & congruent triangles
description: Solve geometry problems with various polygons by using all you know about similarity and congruence.

title: 2D vs. 3D objects
description: Visualize the relation between two-dimensional and three-dimensional objects.

title: Features & forms of quadratic functions
description: Learn about the features of quadratic functions, and how to find them given the formula of the function. Also learn about the different forms of quadratic functions: standard, vertex, and factored.

title: Warmup: Features of quadratic functions
description: Have some quick review of finding features of quadratic functions given in different forms.

title: Compare quadratic functions
description: Compare the properties of two quadratic functions, each represented in a different way.

title: Equations of parallel & perpendicular lines
description: Learn all about equations of parallel and perpendicular

title: Triangle similarity & the trigonometric ratios
description: Sal explains how the trigonometric ratios are derived from triangle similarity considerations.

title: Japan
description: Explore the arts and belief systems of Japan.

title: Sectors
description: Learn how to find the area of a sector.

title: Inscribed angles
description: Practice the relationship between inscribed & central angles that are subtended by the same arc length.

title: Proof: Right triangles inscribed in circles
description: Proof showing that a triangle inscribed in a circle having a diameter as one side is a right triangle

title: Challenge problems: Inscribed shapes
description: Solve three challenging problems that apply properties of inscribed shapes to find an arc length or a missing angle.

title: Oceania
description: The great expanse of the Pacific Ocean is inhabited space. Pacific islanders have always been skilled navigators and linguists. For many of these people the ocean is not so much a barrier as a known landscape, across which they travel constantly. Explore the British Museum's unparalleled collection of art and artifacts from the Pacific Islands that make up Polynesia, Melanesia, and Micronesia.

title: Topic D: Lesson 37: Complex numbers intro
Solving quadratics using structure
description: Sal solves (2x-3)^2=4x-6 by substituting p for 2x-3 and obtaining the simpler equation p^2=2p.

title: Completing the square (intro)
description: Practice the method of completing the square with quadratic expressions.

title: Geometry proof problem: squared circle
description: Sal finds a missing angle using triangle congruence in a diagram that contains sector of a circle inscribed within a square.

title: Worked example: quadratic formula (negative coefficients)
description: Sal solves -3x^2+10x-3=0 by plugging a=-3, b=10, c=-3 in the quadratic formula. Then he multiplies everything by -1 and solves again. The results are the same!

title: Discriminant review
description: The discriminant is the part of the quadratic formula underneath the square root symbol: b²-4ac. The discriminant tells us whether there are two solutions, one solution, or no solutions.

title: Music basics
description: The basic principles of music are explained in plain language with helpful graphics and live video demonstrations. If you have ever wondered “How does music work?” then you’ll find answers here. Presented by the All-Star Orchestra music director Gerard Schwarz.

title: Trigonometric ratios in right triangles
description: Sal shows a few examples where he starts with the two legs of a right triangle and he finds the trig ratios of one of the acute angles.

title: Finding arc measures
description: Watch Sal solve a few problems where he finds a missing arc measure.

title: Right triangle word problem
description: Sal solves a modeling problem where he finds the necessary angle to shoot at a vicious alien.

title: South Asia
description: From Hindu temples to elephant thrones, explore the belief systems and arts of South Asia.

title: Proof: perpendicular lines have negative reciprocal slope
description: Sal proves that perpendicular lines have negative reciprocal slope using triangle similarity.

title: Law of cosines
description: Learn about the Law of cosines and how to use it in order to find missing side lengths and angles in general triangles.

title: 5. Life
description: What makes life so special? Is there life elsewhere in the Universe? And how exactly did life emerge and diversify? In many ways these remain mysteries, but we do have enough evidence to explore some possible answers.

title: 10. The Future
description: What does 13.8 billion years of history tell you about yourself? How does knowing so much about the past change the way you think about the future? These may be the most important questions Big History asks. How would you answer them? Big History is an unfinished story.

title: Law of demand
description: If the price of something goes up, people are going to buy less of it.

title: Inferior goods clarification
description: More clarification on inferior and normal goods

title: Find angles in congruent triangles
description: Given two triangles, determine whether they are congruent and use that to find missing angle measures.

title: Proof: Rhombus diagonals are perpendicular bisectors
description: Sal proves that the diagonals of a rhombus are perpendicular, and that they intersect at the midpoints of both.

title: Proof: there's an irrational number between any two rational numbers
description: Sal proves that when given any two rational numbers, no matter how close, we can find an irrational number that lies between them.

title: Challenging similarity problem
description: Interesting similarity problem where we don't have a lot of information to work with

title: Quadratic formula proof review
description: A text-based proof (not video) of the quadratic formula

title: Dividing line segments
description: Think about ratios of lengths of segments between points.

title: Area & perimeter on the coordinate plane
description: Find the area or perimeter of shapes like triangles, rectangles, parallelograms, and hexagons on the coordinate plane.

title: Solving for a side in right triangles with trigonometry
description: Learn how to use trig functions to find an unknown side length in a right triangle.

title: Parallel lines from equation
description: Sal determines which pairs out of a few given linear equations are parallel.

title: Radians & degrees
description: Sal discusses the general approach to converting between radians and degrees and vice versa.

title: Trig word problem: complementary angles
description: Sal solves a problem about a submerged pyramid using the fact that the sine of an angle is equal to the cosine of its complementary angle.

title: Area of a sector
description: A worked example of finding the area of a circle's sector using the area of the circle and the central angle of the sector.

title: Challenge problems: Inscribed angles
description: Solve two challenging problems that apply the inscribed angle theorem to find an arc measure or an arc length.

title: Allocative efficiency and marginal benefit
description: Marginal Utility and maximization

title: Asia
description: The museum's collection of objects from Asia spans the Neolithic, from about 5000 B.C.E., to the present day. Represented societies and groups range from complex urban civilizations to largely rural communities; they also include the distinctive cultures and ways of life of indigenous people and other minority groups.

title: Total revenue and elasticity
description: Thinking about how total revenue and elasticity are related

title: Subtracting complex numbers
description: Sal subtracts (6-18i) from (2-3i).

title: Solve equations using structure
description: Solve advanced equations by strategically using quadratic factorization methods.

title: Worked example: rational vs. irrational expressions
description: Sal shows how to determine whether the following expressions are rational or irrational: 9 + √(45), √(45)/ (3*√(5)), and 3*√(9).

title: Constructing bisectors of lines & angles
description: With just a compass and a straightedge  (or virtual versions of them), you'll be amazed by how many geometric shapes you can construct perfectly.  This tutorial gets you started with the building block of how to bisect angle and lines (and how to construct perpendicular bisectors of lines).

title: Quadratic formula
description: Solve quadratic equations using the quadratic formula. For example, solve -9x+10x²+8=14.

title: Quadratic standard form
description: In this tutorial, we will learn how to graph quadratic functions given in different forms.

title: Forms & features of quadratic functions
description: Different forms of quadratic functions reveal different features of those functions. Here, Sal rewrites f(x)=x²-5x+6 in factored form to reveal its zeros and in vertex form to reveal its vertex.

title: Circle basics
description: Make sure you're familiar with notation and key terms like radius, diameter, circumference, pi, tangent, secant, and major/minor arcs before you dive into the rest of the circles content.

title: Classifying quadrilaterals on the coordinate plane
description: Watch Sal classify a quadrilateral as a square, rhombus, rectangle, parallelogram, or trapezoid given its four vertices.

title: Subtended angle from arc length
description: Watch Sal solve an example where he finds the central angle given arc length.

title: Writing equations of perpendicular lines
description: Given line A and point P, Sal finds the equation of the line perpendicular to A that passes through P.

title: Arc length as fraction of circumference
description: Sal finds the fraction of an arc length out of the entire circumference using the radian measure of the central angle subtended by the arc.

title: Quadratic equations word problem: triangle dimensions
description: Sal solves a geometry problem using a quadratic equation.

title: Worked example: Rewriting expressions by completing the square
description: Sal rewrites x²+16x+9 as (x+8)²-55 by completing the square.

title: Completing the square review
description: Completing the square is a technique for factoring quadratics. This article reviews the technique with examples and even lets you practice the technique yourself.

title: Solving modeling problems with similar & congruent triangles
description: Now that you are an expert with solving geometry problems using congruence and similarity, you are ready to solve some real-world problems!

title: Ways to cross-section a cube
description: Learn about all the different ways we can obtain cross-sections of a cube.

title: Dividing line segments: graphical
description: Watch Sal figure out the coordinates of a point between two other points that give a certain ratio. A graph is given to make it easier to visualize the problem.

title: Features of quadratic functions
description: Find the zeroes ("roots") of quadratic functions and the vertex of their parabolas. Functions are given in standard, vertex, and factored form.

title: Graphing quadratics review
description: The graph of a quadratic function is a parabola, which is a "u"-shaped curve. In this article, we review how to graph quadratic functions.

title: Scaling & reflecting parabolas
description: The graph of y=k⋅x² is the graph of y=x² scaled by a factor of |k|. If k<0, it's also reflected (or "flipped") across the x-axis. In this worked example, we find the equation of a parabola from its graph.

title: Trig challenge problem: verify identities
description: Sal is given a diagram with multiple right triangles and is asked to verify identities relating to trig ratios in those triangles.

title: Hinduism
description: Explore the beliefs, practices, and arts of Hinduism.

title: 1. What Is Big History?
description: Where did everything come from? How did we get to where we are now? Where do humans fit in? Where are things heading? These are questions that origin stories of different cultures have addressed for thousands of years. Big History attempts to answer them by examining the entire past of the Universe using the best available ideas from disciplines such as astronomy, chemistry, biology, and history. Throughout the course, you’ll explore different scales of time and space and view human history from new angles. You’ll learn what we know and what we don’t, consider our place in the Universe, and develop your own ideas for what the future may hold.

title: Solving general triangles
description: Use the power of trigonometry in order to solve various problems that involve triangles.

title: Inscribed shapes: find diameter
description: Find the diameter of a circle using an inscribed right triangle.

title: Inscribed quadrilaterals proof
description: Sal uses the inscribed angle theorem and some algebra to prove that opposite angles of an inscribed quadrilateral are supplementary.

title: Irrational numbers
description: Learn what irrational numbers are. Also learn how to classify numbers as whole, integer, rational, and irrational.

title: Proving slope is constant using similarity
description: Sal uses a clever proof involving similar triangles to show that slope is constant for a line.

title: Angle bisector theorem
description: Learn about the angle bisector theorem, which makes a clever use of triangle similarity in order to find a special proportion that holds for angle bisectors of triangles.

title: Volume and surface area of cylinders
description: Find volumes and surface areas of cylinders.

title: Finding the vertex of a parabola in standard form
description: Sal rewrites the equation y=-5x^2-20x+15 in vertex form (by completing the square) in order to identify the vertex of the corresponding parabola.

title: Special right triangles proof (part 2)
description: Showing the ratios of the sides of a 45-45-90 triangle are 1:1:sqrt(2)

title: Hypotenuse, opposite, and adjacent
description: In a right triangle, the hypotenuse is the longest side, an "opposite" side is the one across from a given angle, and an "adjacent" side is next to a given angle.

title: Arc measure
description: Use the fact that the arc measures of a circle must sum to 360 degrees to find missing arc measures.

title: Parallel lines from equation (example 2)
description: Sal determines which pairs out of a few given linear equations are parallel.

title: Southeast Asia
description: Only in the past sixty years has “Southeast Asia” been used to refer to the region comprising modern-day Burma (Myanmar), Thailand, Laos, Cambodia, Vietnam, Malaysia, Singapore, Indonesia, Brunei, and the Philippines. These ten countries cover an area more than three times that of Great Britain, France, and Germany combined, and they have a population about twice as great.

title: Law of sines
description: Learn about the Law of sines and how to use it in order to find missing side lengths and angles in general triangles.

title: The American Diplomatic Toolbox
description: Discussions about American diplomacy in historical and contemporary contexts.

title: Economic growth through investment
description: How investing for capital formation can expand the production possibilities curve

title: Solving inscribed quadrilaterals
description: Example showing supplementary opposite angles in inscribed quadrilateral.

title: Law of supply
description: If the price of something goes up, companies are willing (and able) to produce more of it.

title: Antiquities
description: Greek vases with stories to tell, ancient glass and carved marble, Roman silver and exotic gems—explore the artistry and history of precious antiquities.

title: Total utility and marginal utility
description: In this tutorial we look at the utility of getting one more of something and put numbers to it.  We then use this to construct a budget line and think about indifference curves.

title: Finding angles in isosceles triangles
description: The measures of two angles of an isosceles triangle are 3x+5 and x+16. Find all possible values of x.

title: Worked example: rational vs. irrational expressions (unknowns)
description: Sal determines whether expressions with unknown rational/irrational numbers are rational or irrational.

title: Geometric constructions: perpendicular bisector
description: Sal constructs a perpendicular bisector to a given line segment using compass and straightedge.

title: Geometry word problem: the golden ratio
description: Triangle similarity, the Golden ratio, and art, all converge in this inspiring video!

title: Special right triangles
description: We hate to pick favorites, but there really are certain right triangles that are more special than others.  In this tutorial, we pick them out, show why they're special, and prove it!  These include 30-60-90 and 45-45-90 triangles (the numbers refer to the measure of the angles in the triangle).

title: Band instrument lessons
description:
Learn about band instruments from expert musicians with the United States Marine Band. 

Lessons include warm-ups, excerpts, and helpful advice.  Established by an Act of Congress

in 1798, the United States Marine Band is America’s oldest continuously active professional

musical organization. The Marine Band performs at the White House an average of 200 times

each year, and also presents annually an indoor concert series, summer concerts on the 

National Mall, and a national concert tour.

title: Points inside/outside/on a circle
description: Sal uses the distance formula to determine whether the point (-6,-6) is inside, outside, or on the circle centered at (-1,-3) with radius 6.

title: Solve for a side in right triangles
description: Given one side length and an acute angle in a right triangle, find another side using trigonometry.

title: Angles of elevation and depression
description: Learn what  the terms angle of elevation and angle of depression mean. The words may be big but their meaning is pretty basic!

title: Trig challenge problem: trig values & side ratios
description: Sal is given a diagram with multiple right triangles and is asked to match different expressions with different trig values.

title: Buddhism
description: Discover the beliefs, practices, and arts of Buddhism.

title: Solving for a side with the law of cosines
description: Learn how to use the law of cosines to find the missing side length of a triangle when given two side lengths and the contained angle measure.

title: 6. Early Humans
description: Humans are unusual. We walk upright and build cities, we travel from continent to continent in hours, and we communicate across the globe in an instant. We alone can build bombs and invent medicines. Why can we do all these things that other creatures can’t? What makes us so different from other species?

title: Inscribed shapes: angle subtended by diameter
description: One method using an inscribed angle intercepting a diameter of a circle.

title: Europe
description: The museum's collection covers a vast expanse of time from the earliest times to the present day, including the history of Britain under Roman occupation.

title: Quadratic equations word problem: box dimensions
description: Sal solves a volume problem using a quadratic equation.

title: Worked example: Solving equations by completing the square
description: Sal solves x²-2x-8=0 by rewriting the equation as (x-1)²-9=0 (which is done by completing the square!).

title: The quadratic formula
description: Learn how to solve any quadratic equation with the most general tool of all, the quadratic formula!

title: Using the quadratic formula: number of solutions
description: Sal determines how many solutions the equation x²+14x+49=0 has by considering its quadratic formula, and more specifically, its discriminant.

title: Midpoint formula
description: Learn how to use the midpoint formula to find the midpoint of a line segment on the coordinate plane, or find the endpoint of a line segment given one point and the midpoint.

title: Area of a regular hexagon
description: Using what we know about triangles to find the area of a regular hexagon

title: Circles glossary
description: Formal definition of a circle. Tangent and secant lines. Diameters and radii. major and minor arcs

title: Parallel & perpendicular lines on the coordinate plane
description: You probably know what parallel and perpendicular lines are. In this tutorial, you will learn how these relationships are expressed on the coordinate plane (spoiler: parallel lines have the same slope, and the product of the slopes of perpendicular lines is always -1).

title: Arc length
description: Relate the length of an arc to the circumference of a whole circle and the central angle subtended by the arc.

title: The Himalayas and the Tibetan Buddhist World
description: Discover the arts and cultures of the "roof of the world."

title: Arc length from subtended angle: radians
description: Sal finds the length of an arc using the radius and the radian measure of the angle subtended by the arc.

title: Area of a sector
description: Relate the area of a sector to the area of a whole circle.

title: Inscribed angle theorem proof
description: Proving that an inscribed angle is half of a central angle that subtends the same arc.

title: The production possibilities frontier and social choices
description: Read about how economists think about tradeoffs. We can't do everything we want to!

title: Inscribed quadrilaterals
description: Use the fact that opposite angles in an inscribed quadrilateral are supplementary to solve a few problems.

title: Introduction to health care in the U.S.
description: This tutorial introduces the structure of the U.S. health care system, how money flows within it, and an overview of different types of public and private insurance. These videos and questions provide a clear explanation of what is and is not working within the health care system to help frame the health care reform discussion and inform clinicians and the public how to improve quality while decreasing health care spending.  Narrated by Dr. Darshak Sanghavi, a pediatric cardiologist and fellow at Brookings Institution.

title: Proof: Radius is perpendicular to tangent line
description: Sal proves that the radius that connects the intersection point of a tangent line with the circle is perpendicular to the tangent line.

title: Quadratic word problems (vertex form)
description: Given a quadratic function that models the height of an object being launched from a platform, we analyze the function to answer questions like "what is the height of the platform?" or "when does the object reach its maximum height?"

title: Contemporary Sculptors at the British Museum
description: The British Museum has one of the world’s most celebrated and diverse collections of sculpture, dating from prehistory to the present day. Since its foundation in 1753, the Museum has consistently engaged with the contemporary world, both in its collecting and its displays.

title: Determining tangent lines: lengths
description: Solve two problems that apply properties of tangents to determine if a line is tangent to a circle.

title: Utility maximization: equalizing marginal utility per dollar
description: Why the marginal utility for dollar spent should be theoritically equal for the last increment of either good purchased

title: Proof: Segments tangent to circle from outside point are congruent
description: Sal proves that two tangent segments to a circle that are drawn from the same outside point are congruent.

title: Market equilibrium
description: You understand demand and supply.  This tutorial puts it all together by thinking about where the two curves intersect.  This point represents the equilibrium price and quantity which is, in an ideal world, where the market would transact.

title: Deriving demand curve from tweaking marginal utility per dollar
description: Seeing what happens to quantity demanded when price changes

title: Decorative arts
description: Discover the exquisitely crafted objects used in the daily life of European aristocracy. Also explore maiolica from Spain and Italy, and learn about the history and making of stained glass.

title: Changes in equilibrium price and quantity: the four-step process
description: Let's look at some step-by-step examples of shifting supply and demand curves.

title: Sculpture
description: A polychromed saint, a juggling man cast in bronze, and magnificent marble throughout the ages—explore the making and meaning of different types of sculpted treasures.

title: What drives oil prices
description: This tutorial tries to address a very important question in the real world--what drives oil prices?  And we will do it using the tools of the supply and demand curves.

title: Photographs
description: Learn about some of the very first photographic techniques, and discover photographs of the early 1800s to the present. Hear artists discuss their images and processes.

title: Challenge problems: radius & tangent
description: Solve two challenging problems that apply properties of tangents to find the radius of a circle with a tangent.

title: Decisions within a budget constraint
description: Read about how an economist would think about making decisions within a budget constraint

title: Price elasticity of demand
description: You're familiar with supply and demand curves already.  In this tutorial we'll explore what implications their steepness (or lack of) implies.  Price elasticity is a measure of how sensitive something is to price.

title: Challenge problems: circumscribing shapes
description: Solve two challenging problems that apply properties of tangents to find the perimeter of a circumscribing shape.

title: Standard equation of a circle
description: Learn about the standard form to represent a circle with an equation. For example, the equation (x-1)^2+(y+2)^2=9 is a circle whose center is (1,-2) and radius is 3.

title: Features of a circle from its standard equation
description: Sal finds the center and the radius of the circle whose equation is (x+3)^2+(y-4)^2=49.

title: Average costs (ATC, MC) and marginal revenue (MR)
description: In this tutorial, Sal uses the example of an orange juice business to help us understand the ideas of average total cost (ATC), marginal cost (MC) and marginal revenue (MR).  We then use this understanding to answer the age-old question, "how much orange juice should I produce?"  Finally, we use these ideas to construct a long-run supply curve.  A must watch if you're interested in making juice!

title: 82nd & Fifth
description: The Met's 82nd & Fifth is an award-winning online series, in which curators talk about works of art that have changed the way they see the world: one curator, one work, two minutes at a time. http://82nd-and-fifth.metmuseum.org/

title: Price elasticity of demand and price elasticity of supply
description: How do quantities supplied and demanded react to changes in price?

title: Marginal cost and average total cost
description: Looking at marginal and average total cost in the context of a juice business

title: Extravagant Inventions
description: On what did the rulers of late eighteenth-century Europe spend their money? On wars, palaces, and the arts—but also extravagant mechanical furniture. Both the King of Prussia and the Empress of Russia entertained themselves and their guests with ingeniously concealed and automated drawers as well as hidden compartments built within some of the most elegant desks and tables ever devised.

title: Perfect inelasticity and perfect elasticity of demand
description: Extreme examples of price elasticity of demand

title: Making, finding, and conserving
description: Go behind the scenes at The Metropolitan Museum of Art to explore how some of the world's finest art was created, how it is conserved, and even how it was discovered.

title: Graph a circle from its standard equation
description: Given the standard form equation of a circle, graph the circle. For example, graph the circle who's equation is (x+5)²+(y+2)²=4.

title: #MetKids: Made for, with, and by kids
description: #MetKids is a digital feature made for, with, and by kids. With fun facts and creative projects for the galleries or at home, #MetKids has been inspired, tested, and approved by real kids ages 7–12. Be part of it!

title: Writing standard equation of a circle
description: Given a circle on the coordinate plane, Sal finds its standard equation, which is an equation in the form (x-a)²+(y-b)²=r².

title: The structure of costs in the short run
description: In the short run, some costs are fixed. You can't do anything about them.

title: The structure of costs in the long run
description: In the long run, you can change anything about your business, so all costs are variable.

title: Expanded equation of a circle
description: Learn how to analyze an equation of a circle that is not given in the standard form. For example, find the center of the circle whose equation is x^2+y^2+4x-5=0.

title: Economic profit and opportunity cost
description: Economic profit and accounting profit are two different things (the difference being that economic profit takes into account opportunity cost).  Confused?  This tutorial lays it all out with the example of a restaurant.

title: Average fixed, variable and marginal costs
description: Using a spreadsheet, Sal walks through an example of average costs per line of code as a firm hires more engineers.  Really good primer to understand what average fixed costs, average variable costs, average total costs (ATC) and average marginal costs (MC) are (and how they are calculated).

title: Elasticity and pricing
description: Read about how a business might set its prices based on what it knows about elasticity of demand and supply

title: Features of a circle from its expanded equation
description: Sal finds the center and the radius of a circle whose equation is x^2+y^2+4x-4y-17=0, and then he graphs the circle.

title: Depreciation and opportunity cost of capital
description: How to account for things when you own the building instead of renting it

title: Visualizing average costs and marginal costs as slope
description: Graphing variable cost, fixed cost and total cost

title: Explicit and implicit costs and accounting and economic profit
description: There are different ways of thinking about costs and profit. Read about what they are!

title: Topic E: First-person video games—projection matrices
Topic B: Lessons 9-11: Unknown angle proofs
Can City Life Help Some Endangered Animals?
Can City Life Help Some Endangered Animals?
Asians Celebrate Lunar New Year Around the World
The Rules of Word Stress, Part 2
Graph a circle from its expanded equation
description: Given the expanded equation of a circle, graph the circle. For example, graph the circle whose equation is x²+y²+4x+8y+16=0.

title: Price discrimination
description: This short tutorial explores how a wine business can utilize first-degree price discrimination to maximize economic profit (it uses many of the ideas we've explored in the rest of this tutorial).

title: Long term supply curve and economic profit
description: Understanding the long term supply curve in terms of economic profit

title: Perfect competition
description: This tutorial looks at markets that are deemed to have "perfect competition."  This means that there are many players with identical products, no barriers to entry, no advantage for existing players and good pricing information.  Few to no real market completely matches this theoretical ideal, but many are close.  Even the example we use in this tutorial (the airline industry) isn't quite perfect (you should think about why).

title: Constructing regular polygons inscribed in circles
description: Have you ever wondered how people would draw a square, equilateral triangle or even hexagon before there were computers?  Well, now you're going to do just that (ironically, with a computer).  Using our virtual compass and straightedge, you'll construct several regular shapes (by inscribing them inside circles).

title: Elasticity and strange percent changes
description: Why we calculate percent changes in a strange way when calculating elasticities

title: Geometric constructions: circle-inscribed square
description: Sal constructs a square that is inscribed inside a given circle using compass and straightedge.

title: Consumer and producer surplus
description: Many times, the equilibrium price is lower than the highest price some folks are willing to pay.  For all consumers, this is called consumer surplus.  Similarly, the price might be higher than the minimum price at which some are willing to produce.  For all the producers, this is called producer surplus.  This tutorial covers them both with an emphasis on the visual.

title: Geometric constructions: circle-inscribed equilateral triangle
description: Sal constructs an equilateral triangle that is inscribed inside a given circle using compass and straightedge.

title: Printmaking
description: Artists have used printmaking to create some of their most profound and compelling works of art, yet the basic printmaking techniques remain a mystery to most people. These videos demonstrate three key printmaking processes—relief, intaglio, and lithography. They include prints from the Museum's collection to demonstrate the range of expressive effects associated with each technique.

title: How perfectly competitive firms make output decisions
description: See examples of how perfectly competitive firms decide how much to produce.

title: Geometric constructions: circle-inscribed regular hexagon
description: Sal constructs a regular hexagon that is inscribed inside a given circle using compass and straightedge.

title: 1913 Centennial Celebration
description: 1913 is a particularly important year within the history of modern art, marked by events and objects that would fundamentally change the way art was conceived and understood. In February of that year, the groundbreaking "Armory Show" introduced the American public to the work of Paul Cézanne, Pablo Picasso, Marcel Duchamp, and many other European artists exhibited alongside their American avant-garde counterparts. In this series of videos, curators from all areas of the Museum speak about their favorite works from 1913 in MoMA's collection.

title: Put as insurance
description: Put as Insurance

title: Constructing circumcircles & incircles
description: In our study of triangles, we spent a decent amount of time think about incenters (the intersections of the angle bisectors) and circumcenters (the intersections of the perpendicular bisectors).  We'll now leverage this knowledge to actually construct circle inscribed and circumscribed about a triangle using only a compass and straightedge (actually virtual versions of them).

title: Entry and exit decisions in the long run
description: Read about how companies decide to enter or exit perfectly competitive markets.

title: Geometric constructions: triangle-inscribing circle
description: Sal constructs a circle that inscribes a given triangle using compass and straightedge.

title: Geometric constructions: triangle-circumscribing circle
description: Sal constructs a circle that circumscribes a given triangle using compass and straightedge.

title: Monopoly
description:
No, we aren't talking about the board game although the game does try to approximate what this tutorial is about--notice that you can charge more rent at either Boardwalk or Park Place if you own both (you have a "monopoly" in the navy blue market).

The opposite of perfect competition is when you have only one firm operating.  This tutorial explores what this firm would do to maximize economic profit.
